resources.string: Application written in Kotlin and C++. It is used to inject payloads or start Lakka on the Switch. Visit /r/SwitchHacks or GBAtemp for tutorials and homebrew.

You will need a cable to connect your device to the Switch. For proper operation, this should be a cable that is designed for data transmission, not just for charging.

It is advisable to use an A-to-C cable with a USB OTG adapter.

If you are having trouble with a C-to-C cable, consider getting an OTG adapter.

Your device does not need root for this to work, however some devices do not support USB OTG. If you are not able to get it to work after trying different cables, try another Android device. Additionally, Android devices with xHCI controllers(USB 3.0) should work fine, but EHCI(USB 2.0) drivers may not work without a kernel patch.

In the "Payloads" category, click the "+" button to add payloads from your device's storage. Or simply transfer your payload to the RCM Loader folder in your device's storage.

Or you can use the default payload, hekate - CTCaer mod v4.0

Hekate is a multipurpose payload that allows you to boot custom firmware with module support, NAND backup/restore options, toggle auto-RCM, launch other payloads on the Switch's sd card, Linux chainloading(You can boot Lakka this way), and more!

If you want to boot into Lakka it is now strongly recommended to use the included hekate payload. Lakka launching will probably be removed from this app in a future release. If you still wish to use this app\'s Lakka launcher continue reading.\n\nIn the \u0022Lakka\u0022 category, click the \u0022Add\u0022 or \u0022Update\u0022 button to select the \u0022coreboot\u0022 file from your device\'s storage. Or simply transfer your \u0022coreboot.rom\u0022 file to the RCM Loader/Lakka folder in the device\'s memory. Tap the question mark (?) to download the needed coreboot file. A download link is also available on the GitHub README in the Play Store description.

"RCM" refers to Tegra Recovery Mode. Enter your Switch into RCM mode in any convenient way. Start by powering off the Switch completely and then bridging pins 10 and 7 (or 10 and 1) together in the right hand side rail. You can use a 3D printed jig or another convenient method such as a paperclip but be careful not to damage your pins. While powered off and the pins bridged, hold down the Volume-Up button and press the power button once while holding Volume-Up and then release. The display should remain blank as if it is still powered off but you are now in RCM mode. If it powers on normally, then you have not bridged your pins correctly and will need to start over.

Once in RCM mode, connect your device to the Switch and select your payload once prompted.

Tap the question mark (?) for a guide on getting into RCM.

Connect the device to the Switch while it is in RCM and allow permission for the USB access if necessary. Wait until the program prompts you to select what you want to inject, Payload or Lakka.

If you will select Payload, than you will have to choose the one you need.

If you will choose Lakka, you should simply wait for it to load.

If you are an absolute beginner, the included payload cannot boot into CFW alone. You will need to have additional files on the SD card of your Switch. Beginners should use SDFilesSwitch by tumGER on GitHub.

Lakka also needs files on your Switch SD in order to work. Visit lakka-switch.github.io/documentation for an install guide.
